methods.description: The ambient dose equivalent rate calculated for a single particle type, or accumulated over all particle types.

parameters.name: altitude
parameters.description: Altitude (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 47 km (the upper limit of the stratosphere).

parameters.name: particle
parameters.description: The particle type as a string. Specifying 'total' returns the dose for all particle types.

methods.description: The effective dose rate calculated for a single particle type, or accumulated over all particle types.

methods.description: The ambient dose equivalent rate calculated for a single particle type, or accumulated over all particle types.

parameters.name: altitude
parameters.description: Altitude (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 47 km (the upper limit of the stratosphere).

parameters.name: atmosphericDepth
parameters.description: Atmospheric depth from the top of the atmosphere (in units of g/cm2). The minimum is 0.913 g/cm2, the maximum is 1032.66 g/cm2. WARNING: you can specify either altitude OR atmospheric depth, not both.

parameters.name: particle
parameters.description: The particle type as a string. Specifying 'total', only used for the dose calculation, returns the dose for all particle types.

methods.description: The energy differential intensity of a particle at a given zenith angle.

parameters.name: altitude
parameters.description: Altitude (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 47 km (the upper limit of the stratosphere).

parameters.name: atmosphericDepth
parameters.description: Atmospheric depth from the top of the atmosphere (in units of g/cm2). The minimum is 0.913 g/cm2, the maximum is 1032.66 g/cm2. WARNING: you can specify either altitude OR atmospheric depth, not both.

parameters.name: particle
parameters.description: The particle type as a string. Specifying 'total', only used for the dose calculation, returns the dose for all particle types.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: Direction cosine. 1.0 is in the downward direction.

methods.description: Calculate the ambient equivalent dose along a great circle flight route.

parameters.name: origin
parameters.description: The ICAO code or IATA code or latitude,longitude pair (in decimal degrees) of the origin airport.

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: The ICAO code or IATA code or latitude,longitude pair (in decimal degrees) of the destination airport.

parameters.name: altitude
parameters.description: Altitude (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 20 km.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The flight duration in hours. The minimum is 0, the maximum is 20 hrs.

parameters.name: initialAltitude
parameters.description: Initial altitude (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 20 km.

parameters.name: cruisingAltitudes
parameters.description: Cruising altitudes (in km). The minimum is 0 m, the maximum is 20 km.

parameters.name: climbTimes
parameters.description: Climb times for each cruising altitude (hours).

parameters.name: cruisingTimes
parameters.description: Cruising times at each cruising altitude (hours).

parameters.name: descentTime
parameters.description: Descent time from last cruising altitude to final altitude (hours).

parameters.description: Descent time from last cruising altitude to final altitude (hours).

apiDescription:
Our atmosphere protects us from a hostile space radiation environment comprising high energy particles of solar and intergalactic origin. Solar radiation is significant during unpredictable and short lived solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs); however, galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) is omnipresent. The GCR intensity varies with latitude, longitude, and time due to effects of solar activity on the interplanetary magnetic field, as well as the Earth's magnetic field. Space radiation collides with gases in the atmosphere, leading to a complex shower of high energy radiation, the intensity and composition of which varies spatially and temporally. Excessive exposure to radiation can damage DNA and lead to long-term health effects such as an increased risk of cancer.

Resulting radiation levels at commercial aircraft altitudes are greater than at sea level. Aircrew are classified as radiation workers in some countries; however, planning to limit their exposure, and monitoring, is generally lacking. Both real-time measurements and predictive models of radiation in the atmosphere are important to mitigate the radiation risk to crew.

We host a RESTful API to models of cosmic ray induced ionising radiation in the atmosphere. The CARI7 and PARMA endpoints use models developed by the US Federal Aviation Administration and the Japan Atomic Energy Agency to calculate cosmic radiation doses at a point. The Route Dose API calculates the same quantities along a great circle route between two airports using CARI7.

API requests must contain a key "API-Key" in the header (see code samples). Obtain a key from here.

Help us improve the quality of our web APIs by completing our 2 minute survey here.

Amentum Pty Ltd is not responsible nor liable for any loss or damage of any sort incurred as a result of using the API.
